answers.a: No—despite the name, it isn’t a dairy ingredient and contains no milk proteins or lactose; it’s made from lactic acid (from fermentation, not milk) and stearic acid.

answers.q: is sodium stearoyl lactylate bad for you
answers.a: It’s considered safe at permitted food-use levels by regulators (e.g., FDA and EU), and most people tolerate it well; adverse effects are uncommon at typical dietary intakes.
Not always—stearic acid can come from either animal fat or vegetable oils, so vegans should verify the source with the manufacturer.

answers.q: what is sodium stearoyl lactylate made of
answers.a: It’s a mixture of sodium salts of stearoyl lactylic acids, produced from lactic acid and stearic acid.

answers.q: how is sodium stearoyl lactylate made
answers.a: It’s made by esterifying stearic acid with lactic acid, then partially neutralizing the product with sodium hydroxide or sodium carbonate to form the sodium salts.
